summary: I recently finalized my doctoral research project with the title "Scandinavism: Overlapping and Competing Identities in the Nordic World, 1770-1919." While writing my dissertation I could fully employ my creativity, analytical abilities, and research skills. Currently I am looking for a new job that enables me to apply my talents for a challenging and worthy cause, whether that may be within or outside academia. My main interest are cultural history, art, literature, Scandinavia, but also pressing political issues such as the debates on national identity, the EU and climate change.

awards: [{'title': 'Nordic History Book Award 2022', 'description': 'At the opening ceremony for the Congress of Nordic Historians on 8 August, it was announced that the winner of the 2022 Nordic History Book Award is\xa0Tim van Gerven\xa0for\xa0Scandinavism: Overlapping and Competing Identities in the Nordic World, 1770–1919\xa0(Brill 2022). Read more about the book\xa0here.\n\nThe purpose of the Nordic History Book Award is to stimulate historical interest in the Nordic region. It is given to the author/s of the most innovative and thoughtful historical recent work in Nordic history. The Award was initiated by the Committee of Nordic Historians, consisting of representatives of the national historical associations, in collaboration with\xa0Scandinavian Journal of History\xa0and the Centre for Nordic Studies at the University of Helsinki (CENS). The first award was presented at the 29th\xa0Congress of Nordic Historians in Aalborg 2017.', 'issuer': 'Committee of Nordic Historians', 'date': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}}, {'title': 'Mobility Grant for Norwegian Language and Literature', 'description': 'Mobility Grant for a 2-month research stay at the University of Oslo. ', 'issuer': 'Norwegian Agency for International Cooperation and Quality Enhancement in Higher Education', 'date': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}]
projects:
[{'title': 'Scandinavism: overlapping and competing identities in the Nordic world', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'In the European nation-building process, the shifting demarcations and power relations between the states of Northern Europe, and the emergence of a separate ethnolinguistic self-awareneness among Norwegian, Finnish, and Icelandic groups, has been well studied. The resulting model risks being both finalistic (in that it highlights those processes which were eventually consolidated in state-formation) and competitive-secessionist (in that it highlights processes where ethnic groups opt out of existing states).

A proper intellectual-historical and comparative-macroregional approach should also take intoaccount those processes which, without achieving political consolidation, played a more transnationalrole in cultural mobilization by propounding alternative cultural identities across existing state structures. Besides a widespread Romantic interest in a putative Nordic sea empire involving the shores of North America, the most salient phenomenon is that of Scandinavism. While Scandinavism has been well studied, particularly as a failed political ideal, the current PhD-project aims to thematize Scandinavism as a primarily cultural movement, which, notwithstanding its failure as a political mobilizer, strengthened and extended national consciousness-raising in the various Nordic nationalities by stressing common ethnolinguistic, mythological and historical roots. This cultural vision is to be traced in the ‘Long 19th Century’ specifically in its cultural presence (as critical discourse and literary activism) and in its interactions and overlaps with the various nationally-specific manifestations of cultural nationalism, following the model of the ‘cultivation of culture’ developed by the Study Platform on Interlocking Nationalism.

The project is supervised by prof. dr. Joep Leerssen, prof. dr. Henk van der Liet, dr. Suze van der Poll and dr. Kim Simonsen.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Tim', 'last_name': 'van Gerven', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Associate Professor in Nineteenth-Century History'}]}]

My research aims to extend this general perception of Nordic pan-nationalism by analyzing it as a primarily cultural movement, for Scandinavism, and its significance for the specific national identities that developed over the course of the nineteenth century, can only be properly understood if one takes its cultural aspects into account. The analysis takes its starting point in the discursive instrumentalisation of Old Norse and medieval mythology and literature. This rich literary heritage was both a source of solidarity between the three 'brother nations' as a probable cause for conflict and competition. As such, Scandinavism strengthened a sense of a shared culture and linguistic and historical roots at the same time as it undermined these sentiments of togetherness. It is the main aim of my research to survey and analyze this interaction between Scandinavism and the various nationally-specific manifestations of cultural nationalism in the 'Long Nineteenth Century' (1789-1914).", 'title': 'PhD Candidate', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 5570, 'name': 'Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/D4E0BAQGFG964atm3Ow/company-logo_400_400/0/1682661887840?e=1700092800&v=beta&t=9_w6JN2W8tFzLfJtY_8RcNmqQZzGUlcMXQLryo-X764', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/vrije-universiteit-amsterdam/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'company': 'Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU Amsterdam)', 'description': "Working for the Education Office of the Bèta VU Faculty, my responsibilities included the secretarial support of the Examination Board and several Programme Committees as well as of the so-called 'BSA Committee' and the 'Harde Knip Committee'.
